revision.text:
{{distinguish|text= the Filipino musical genre [[Kundiman]]}}
[[File:Kundiman Booth.jpg|thumb|Kundiman Booth at AWP 2018]] '''Kundiman''' is a nonprofit organization which offers writing retreats, a reading series, a youth leadership intensive,<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://kundiman.org/youth|title=Youth Leadership|website=Kundiman|language=en-US|access-date=2018-02-14}}</ref> and a poetry prize, and is dedicated to providing "a safe yet rigorous space where Asian American poets can explore, through art, the unique challenges that face the new and ever changing diaspora."<ref>[http://www.kundiman.org/%5BCLB%5D_Brightside/1.Source/kundiman.html Kundiman > Mission]</ref> Kundiman was co-founded in 2004<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://kundiman.org/what-is-kundiman/|title=What is Kundiman?|website=Kundiman|language=en-US|access-date=2018-05-27}}</ref> by Asian American poets [[Sarah Gambito]] and Joseph O. Legaspi,<ref>[http://www.kundiman.org/%5BCLB%5D_Brightside/1.Source/people.html Kundiman > People]</ref><ref>[http://www.kundiman.org/Affiliation%20Press%20Release.pdf Kundiman > Recent News > Press Release > Kundiman, Inc & Fordham University announce Partnership Agreement >]</ref> and has received support from the [[National Endowment for the Arts]], the [[Geraldine R. Dodge Foundation]], [[University of Virginia]], Asian American Arts Alliance’s (SOAR) Program, Philippine American Writers, PAWA, and individuals.<ref>[http://www.kundiman.org/%5BCLB%5D_Brightside/1.Source/sponsors.html Kundiman > Sponsors]</ref>
Recently, Kundiman and [[Fordham University]] announced that they have formed an affiliation: Kundiman will "enhance the outreach of Fordham’s English Department," and Fordham will host the annual Kundiman Poetry Retreat on [[Campuses_of_Fordham_University#Rose_Hill_campus|Fordham’s Rose Hill campus]] beginning in 2010, and host Kundiman-sponsored readings and events at the Lincoln Center Campus. Fordham will also provide a total of $60,000 over three years in financial support for Kundiman’s programs.<ref>[http://www.kundiman.org/Affiliation%20Press%20Release.pdf Kundiman > Recent News > Press Release > Kundiman, Inc & Fordham University announce Partnership Agreement >]</ref>
According to the University of Virginia, which hosted Kundiman's inaugural writing retreat, "The organization’s name refers to a style of Filipino love song that served as veiled patriotism during colonial times."<ref>[http://www.virginia.edu/topnews/releases2004/asian-july-30-2004.html University of Virginia > News > July 30, 2004 > ''First National Retreat For Asian-American Poets To Be Held At U.Va. Aug. 4-8'']</ref> According to Sarah Gambito, "Kundiman Fellows have published poems in ''The Virginia Quarterly Review,The Colorado Review, Pleiades, Black Warrior Review'' and ''Crab Orchard Review''."<ref>[http://asianamericanpoetry.blogspot.com/2009_03_01_archive.html ''Asian-American Poetry'' > Saturday, March 28, 2009 > ''Kundiman - Letter from Executive Director Sarah Gambito '']</ref> There have been over 180 books published by Kundiman fellows.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://kundiman.org/fellowpublicationslist|title=fellowpublicationslist|website=Kundiman|language=en-US|access-date=2018-05-27}}</ref>
Honors given by Kundiman include '''The Kundiman Poetry Prize,''' for a book by an Asian American poet at any stage in their career.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://kundiman.org/prize|title=Prize|website=Kundiman|language=en-US|access-date=2018-05-12}}</ref> The winning manuscript is published by [[Tupelo Press]],<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://kundiman.org/prize|title=Prize|website=Kundiman|language=en-US|access-date=2018-05-12}}</ref>, and according to Kundiman, "is the only poetry prize dedicated to Asian American poets in the country."<ref>[http://www.kundiman.org/%5BCLB%5D_Brightside/1.Source/news.html Kundiman > Recent News] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090507082620/http://www.kundiman.org/%5BCLB%5D_Brightside/1.Source/news.html |date=2009-05-07 }}</ref><ref>[http://www.pw.org/content/alice_james_books_and_kundiman_present_book_prize_asian_american_poets ''Poets & Writers'' > ''G&A: The Contest Blog'' > Alice James ''Books and Kundiman Present Book Prize for Asian American Poets'' > July 14, 2009]</ref><ref>[http://www.kundiman.org/Affiliation%20Press%20Release.pdf Kundiman > Recent News > Press Release > Kundiman, Inc & Fordham University announce Partnership Agreement >]</ref>
== Kundiman Retreat == The Kundiman Retreat was started in 2004 by [[Sarah Gambito]] and [[Joseph O. Legaspi.]] The inaugural Retreat was hosted at the University of Virginia in 2004.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://kundiman.org/what-is-kundiman/|title=What is Kundiman?|website=Kundiman|language=en-US|access-date=2018-05-12}}</ref> It now takes place at [[Fordham University]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://kundiman.org/retreat/|title=Retreat|website=Kundiman|language=en-US|access-date=2018-05-12}}</ref> Poet Duy Doan said of the Kundiman Retreat: "I would never be able to overemphasize the positive impact that the Kundiman retreats have had on me—writing, musing, connecting with other Asian–Pacific Islander American writers, being taken in by a richly talented and generous community."<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.pw.org/content/where_big_books_are_born_duy_doan_on_the_kundiman_retreat|title=Where Big Books Are Born: Duy Doan on the Kundiman Retreat|date=2018-02-14|work=Poets & Writers|access-date=2018-05-12|language=en}}</ref> Poet [[Chen Chen]] said that the Kundiman Retreat was "really magical and opened up my eyes to what was possible in the Asian American literary community."<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://aaww.org/writing-the-families-we-want-an-interview-with-chen-chen/|title=Writing the Families We Want: An Interview with Chen Chen|date=2017-12-19|work=Asian American Writers' Workshop|access-date=2018-05-27|language=en-US}}</ref>
Some Kundiman fellows include:
* [[Fatimah Asghar]] * [[Cathy Linh Che]] * [[Chen Chen]] * Duy Doan * [[Zahir Janmohamed]] * [[Hieu Minh Nguyen]] * [[Sadia Shepard]] * [[Ocean Vuong]] * Jenny Xie<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://kundiman.org/fellows/|title=Fellows|website=Kundiman|language=en-US|access-date=2018-05-12}}</ref>
==See also== * [[CantoMundo]] * [[Cave Canem Foundation]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.kundiman.org Kundiman Website] * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=tBkWDxMoYo0 Video: 2005 Kundiman Retreat Readings]

[[Image:Grande Ludovisi Altemps Inv8574.jpg|thumb|upright=1.5|Relief panel of the Great Ludovisi sarcophagus]]
The '''Ludovisi Battle sarcophagus''' or '''"Great" Ludovisi sarcophagus''' is an [[ancient Roman sarcophagus]] dating to around AD 250–260 from a tomb near the [[Porta Tiburtina]]. It is also known as the '''Via Tiburtina Sarcophagus''', though other sarcophagi have been found there. It is known for its densely populated, anti-[[classicism|classical]] composition of "writhing and highly emotive"<ref name="Kleiner 272">Fred S. Kleiner, ''A History of Roman Art'' (Wadsworth, 2007, 2010, enhanced ed.), p. 272.</ref> [[ancient Romans|Romans]] and [[Goths]], and is an example of the battle scenes favored in [[Roman art]] during the [[Crisis of the Third Century]].<ref name="Kleiner 272" /> Discovered in 1621 and named for its first modern owner, [[Ludovico Ludovisi]], the sarcophagus is now displayed at the [[Palazzo Altemps]] in [[Rome]], part of the [[National Museum of Rome]].<ref>Christopher S. Mackay, ''Ancient Rome: A Military and Political History'' (Cambridge University Press, 2004), p. 178.</ref>
The sarcophagus is a late outlier in a group of about twenty-five late Roman battle sarcophagi, the others all apparently dating to 170-210, made in Rome or in some cases [[Athens]]. These derive from [[Hellenistic]] monuments from [[Pergamon]] in [[Asia Minor]] showing Pergamene victories over the [[Gauls]], and were all presumably commissioned for military commanders. The [[Portonaccio sarcophagus]] is the best known and most elaborate of the main [[Antonine]] group and shows both considerable similarities to the Great Ludovisi sarcophagus, and a considerable contrast in style and mood.<ref>Donald Strong et al., ''Roman Art'', 1995 (2nd edn.), p. 205, Yale University Press (Penguin/Yale History of Art), {{ISBN|0300052936}}</ref>
==Description== [[File:Grande Ludovisi sarcophagus 03.JPG|thumb|Detail of the central figure, his forehead marked with an X]] The sarcophagus measures 1.53m in height and is made from [[Proconnesian marble]], a [[List of artistic media|medium]] characterized by dark gray stripes and a medium to coarse grain.<ref>Frances Van Keuren, Donatio Attanasio, John J. Hermann Jr., Norman Herz, and L. Peter Gromet, "Multimethod Analyses of Roman Sarcophagi at the Museo Nazionale Romano, Rome," in ''Life, Death and Representation: Some New Work on Roman Sarcophagi'' (De Gruyter, 2011), p. 181.</ref> It is decorated in a very [[high relief]] with many elements of the composition cut completely free of the background. Overlapping figures entirely fill the image space, allowing no room to depict a background. In many battle sarcophagi the side panels show more tranquil scenes, but here the battle continues round both sides.
The lid of the sarcophagus depicts barbarian children handed over to a Roman general by men presumably their fathers.<ref>Jeannine Diddle Uzzi, "The Power of Parenthood in Official Roman Art," in ''Constructions of Childhood in Ancient Greece and Italy'' (American School of Classical Studies at Athens, 2007), p. 76.</ref> Children were sometimes taken into Roman custody as pledges of peace, and might be reeducated as Romans. The lid, which was broken in 1945 while on display in [[Mainz]], also shows a [[Bust (sculpture)|bust]] of a female figure.
The central figure of the tortuous composition on the front is a young Roman military commander on horseback, presumed to represent the deceased. His face is serene, and his arm is extended confidently in a "gesture which is difficult to interpret but seems to be one of farewell".<ref name="Strong 257" /> An X-mark on his forehead has been interpreted as the cross received by initiates into the [[Mithraic mysteries]] as a sign of the god Mithras' favor. The Mithraic religion was popular among Roman soldiers. The valor ''([[Virtus (virtue)|virtus]])'' shown by the horseman may represent real-life bravery on the battlefield, but the religious connotation of the X may suggest victory over death, a theme of mounted warriors in funerary art. The horseman probably represents the deceased.<ref>Katherine Welch, "Roman Sculpture," in ''The Oxford History of Western Art'' (Oxford University Press, 2000), p. 51; Linda Maria Gigante, "Funerary art," in ''The Oxford Encyclopedia of Ancient Greece and Rome'' (Oxford University Press, 2010), pp. 250–251.</ref>
The figure is sometimes identified as the younger son of the emperor [[Decius]], [[Hostilian]], who reigned briefly in the year 251. Decius and his older son, [[Herennius Etruscus|Herennius]], whom he had made his co-ruler, were killed [[Battle of Abritus|in battle]] against a federation of [[Scythians#Migration period|Scythians]] under the command of the [[Goths|Gothic]] king [[Cniva]]. They were the first [[Roman emperor]]s to die in battle at the hands of a foreign enemy. Despite the battle imagery, Hostilian himself died of plague.<ref>Tony Allan, ''Life, Myth, And Art In Ancient Rome'' (Duncan Baird, 2005), p. 52.</ref>
[[File:Grande Ludovisi sarcophagus 21.JPG|thumb|upright|left|Roman wearing mail, and above him a ''[[cornicen]]'', a junior officer who communicated signals with the [[cornu (horn)|military horn]]]] The sarcophagus contains many precise depictions of military details such as the ''[[Draco (military standard)|draco]]'' military standard and a detailed [[Mail (armour)|mail shirt]] of the longer length characteristic of the period.<ref>Pat Southern and Karen R. Dixon, ''The Late Roman Army'' (Yale University Press, 1996), pp. 98, 126.</ref>
==Technique and style== The undercutting of the deep relief exhibits virtuosic and very time-consuming drill work that conveys chaos and a sense of weary, open-ended victory. It differs from earlier battle scenes on sarcophagi in which more shallowly carved figures are less convoluted and intertwined.<ref>Welch, "Roman Sculpture", in ''The Oxford History of Western Art'', p. 41; Mackay, ''Ancient Rome'', p. 178.</ref> Describing it as "the finest of the third-century sarcophagi", art historian Donald Strong says:<ref name="Strong 257">Donald Strong et al., ''Roman Art'', 1995 (2nd edn.), p. 257, Yale University Press (Penguin/Yale History of Art), {{ISBN|0300052936}}</ref>
{{bquote|The faces are strikingly unclassical, and the technique of deep drilling is particularly obvious in the manes of the horses and the shaggy hair of the barbarians. But the main difference [to the [[Portonaccio sarcophagus]], a similar 2nd-century work] is in the symbolism. The barbarians all seem frozen in the moment before disaster and death overwhelm them; their attitudes are highly theatrical but none the less immensely expressive... The main theme is no longer the glorification of military prowess but that of transcending the struggle, presumably conveying the notion of triumph over death ... The ugliness of pain and suffering is stressed by the dishevelled hair, the tormented eyes, the twisted mouth.}}
The carving is so deep that the forms are almost completely offset from the background resulting in three, or even four, layers of various figures and forms. What is more, overlapping figures fill the image space entirely, allowing no room to depict a background. Thus, the sense of space has been eliminated, giving rise to chaos and a sense of weary, open-ended victory. The effect of movement in the scene is evident and, unlike many battle sarcophagi which have more tranquil scenes on the side panels, the battle events continue all the way around the sarcophagus. The perspective constructed is also notable, although certainly not linear.{{Citation needed|date=December 2016}}
[[File:Grande Ludovisi Altemps Inv8574 n7.jpg|thumb|Detail of a barbarian pierced by a lance,]] From the time of the [[Antonine dynasty|reign of the Antonine emperors]], Roman art increasingly depicted battles as chaotic, packed, single-plane scenes presenting dehumanized barbarians mercilessly subjugated by Roman military might, at a time when in fact the [[Roman Empire]] was undergoing constant invasions from external threats that led to [[fall of the Roman Empire|the fall of the empire in the West]].<ref>Patrick Coleman, "Barbarians: Artistic Representations", in ''The Oxford Encyclopedia of Ancient Greece and Rome'', p. 371; Allan, ''Life, Myth, And Art In Ancient Rome'', p. 52.</ref> Although armed, the barbarian warriors, usually identified as Goths, are depicted as helpless to defend themselves.<ref>Coleman, "Barbarians: Artistic Representations", p. 371.</ref> Various aspects of the execution of the work accentuate the contrast between the Romans and the Goths. The Roman figures are all clean-shaven and wear armour and helmets, which distinguish them clearly from the Goths, who are unarmoured and wear distinctive clothing, beards, and hairstyles. The Romans are given a nobler appearance with idealised physical features which contrast with the Goths who are almost caricatures, with enlarged noses, pronounced cheekbones, and wild expressions on their faces. The alternation of light/dark accentuates the contrast between the two groups. Shadows and deep carving are mostly found in the faces and hair of the Goths whereas the smooth surface of the marble is reserved for the Romans, who are less deeply carved.
Differences in scale between the figures, though present, are far less marked than in the earlier Portonaccio sarcophagus, such that the general is only slightly larger than his troops or enemies. Nor is the general seen wearing a helmet or in actual combat, as in the earlier sarcophagi.<ref name="Strong 257" />

page.title: Madonna and Child with St Rose and St Catherine

revision.text:
{{Expand French|La Vierge et l'Enfant entourés de deux anges, sainte Rose et sainte Catherine|date=June 2018}} {{Infobox artwork/wikidata|year={{circa}} 1490–1492|location=}} '''''Madonna and Child with St Rose and St Catherine''''' is a c.1490–1492 [[Tondo (art)|tondo]] oil on panel painting by [[Pietro Perugino]] and [[Andrea Aloigi]]. It shows the [[Madonna and Child]] with [[Rose of Viterbo]] and [[Catherine of Alexandria]] surrounded by angels It was sold from the collection of [[William II of the Netherlands]] in 1850 to the [[Louvre]], where it now hangs.
==External links== *http://cartelfr.louvre.fr/cartelfr/visite?srv=car_not_frame&idNotice=13737 *http://www.culture.gouv.fr/public/mistral/joconde_fr?ACTION=CHERCHER&FIELD_1=REF&VALUE_1=000PE026938
[[category:Paintings of the Louvre by Italian artists]] [[category:Perugino Madonnas]] [[category:1492 paintings]] [[category:Paintings of St Catherine of Alexandria|Perugino]] [[Category:Angels in art]]
{{15C-painting-stub}}

{{Arab culture}}
'''Nabataean art''' is the art of the [[Nabataeans]] of North Arabia. They are known for finely-potted painted ceramics, which became dispersed among [[Greco-Roman world]], as well as contributions to sculpture and [[Nabataean architecture]]. Nabataean art is most well known for the archaeological sites in [[Petra]], specifically monuments such as [[Al Khazneh]] and [[Ad Deir]]. [[File:Petra Jordan BW 21.JPG|thumb|right|alt=[[Al Khazneh]] or The Treasury at Petra|[[Al Khazneh]] or The Treasury at Petra]]
==Ceramics== [[File:Nabataean Pottery.JPG|thumb|right|alt=Examples of Nabataean Ceramics|Examples of Nabataean ceramics]] Nabataean pottery is characterized by its thin walls and floral motifs. The exclusive use of floral patterns links back to Nabataean [[aniconism]] in their religious practices. The designs on the wares are generally painted on or pressed into the surface with stamps and rouletting wheels. To put a finish on the pieces, the makers burnished them or used a [[sintering]] process. Most of the wares are pinkish in color, much like the cliffs surrounding the city. This is because Nabataean potters used local clay bodies in their work.<ref>Nabil I. Khairy (Spring, 1983). ''Technical Aspects of Fine Nabataean Pottery''. Bulletin of the American Schools of Oriental Research. No. 250 pp. 17-40</ref> Nabataean wares take many forms, and can be classified by their thickness, rim shape, bases, and decor.<ref name="Hammond">Philip C. Hammond (1962). ''A Classification of Nabataean Fine Ware''. American Journal of Archaeology , Vol. 66, No. 2. pp. 169-180</ref> In some cases, the forms of the vessels mimic the shape of metal wares from the region.<ref>Michael Vickers (Apr., 1994). ''Nabataea, India, Gaul, and Carthage: Reflections on Hellenistic and Roman Gold Vessels and Red-Gloss Pottery''. American Journal of Archaeology, Vol. 98, No. 2. pp. 231-248</ref> These vessels would have been for daily use, not ceremonial, despite the unusually large amount of broken shards found in rubbish heaps.<ref name="Hammond"/>
==Architecture==
===Tombs=== Nabataean tombs are primarily "Rock-Cut tombs." They are created from cutting directly into the landscape, traditionally rock (see [[Rock-cut tombs in Israel]]). Rock-cut tombs are the most frequently found within excavated Nabataean archeological sites. There have been nearly 900 rock-cut tombs found in Petra and Hegra. Nabataean tombs are a fusion Hellenistic and Roman styles as well as a gradual creation of the [[Nabataean]] style. Some offer features of clear Greek influence, such as pediments, metope and triglyph entablatrures, and capitals. They were built to honor Gods and leaders as well as house generations of a specific family. Tombs are located normally inside the city. These tombs are simple in style but elaborated in function, often featuring steps, platforms, libation holes, cisterns, water channels and sometimes banqueting halls. Many feature numerous religious icons, inscriptions, and sanctuaries found in association with springs, catchment pools, and channels.<ref name="Zeyad">Zeyad al-Salameen (2011). ''The Nabataeans and Aisa Minor''. Mediterranean Archaeology and Archaeometry. Vol. 11, No. 2. 55-78.</ref> [[File:Obelisk Tomb and Triclinium.jpg|thumb|right|alt=Obelisk Tomb|Obelisk Tomb]] Crenelated Tombs (see [[crenelation]]) are popular within Nabataean architecture. There are several variations of crenelation, wavering in number of tiers. Crenelated tombs were created in order to represent fortifications, creating a symbol of cities, strength, military power. Later, under Achaemenid Persians, the fortification context was removed, giving a greater scope to a sign of kingship and authority
Several tombs feature [[obelisks]] on their exterior. Obelisks are a narrow tapering monument, often used to represent the [[Nephesh]], specific leaders, and Gods of monolithic societies. They are often found in Near Eastern and Egyptian architecture.
Tombs with detailed [[facades]] are also quite popular in the Nabataean community. There are a total of eight different façade types: Single Pylon, Double Pylon, Step, Proto-Hegr, Hegr, Arch, Simple Classical and Complex Classical. Single Pylon, Double Pylon, Step, Proto-Hegr, and Hegr are characterized by variations on the crowstep motif, combined with elements from classical architecture. Arch, Simple Classical, and Complex Classical have only classical motifs, which have been given Nabataean interpretation.<ref name="Zeyad"/>
At [[Petra]], there is a series of tombs called the "Royal Tombs." These tombs are split into four sections: the Urn Tomb, the Silk Tomb, the Corinthian Tomb, and the Palace Tomb. The Urn Tomb is built high on the mountain side, and requires climbing up a number of flights of stairs. It has been suggested that this is the tomb of Nabataean King Malchus II who died in 70 AD. Beside it is the Silk Tomb, named from its rich color of the sandstone. The Corinthian Tomb is next, featuring Greek Corinthian columns. Finally the Palace Tomb with three distinct stories in its facade.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://nabataea.net/royal.html |title=Petra: The Royal Tombs |publisher=Nabataea.net |date= |accessdate=2013-02-03}}</ref>
==Sculpture== [[File:Camel and riders MET me31 67 2.jpg|right|thumb|upright=0.8|[[Nabataean]] sculpture, camel and riders. ca. 1st century B.C.]] Early Nabataean sculpture had several characteristics of Roman, Greek, and Syrian sculpture. Wild hair, dramatic facial expressions, and S-curves mirrored the Hellenistic style of sculpture. Greek sculpture was represented with the long, tight beards, symmetry, and perfecting of the human body.<ref name="Zeyadine">Zayadine, F. (2003). ''The Nabataean Gods and their Sanctuaries''. Petra Rediscovered: Lost City of the Nabataeans. G. Markoe. New York, Harry N. Abrams, Inc.: 57-64.</ref>
In later years, Nabataean sculpture later became very stylized. Certain elements, such as hair, were kept in the Greco-Roman style, but lots of other things evolved into what’s now understood to be Nabatataean. These characteristics are found in facial structures. The eyes of several pieces are depicted with characteristically flat, cartoonish, semicircular eyes. The same pieces often have triangular noses and large, round chins. Beyond human forms, Nabataean sculpture has come in the form of animals such as birds, elephants, and camels.<ref name="Zeyadine"/>
A number of different Gods and Goddesses are commonly represented throughout Nabataean sculpture. The majority are Gods and Goddesses that were worshiped by the Nabataeans, however some are representative of Greek, Roman, and Middle Eastern beliefs. In addition, the Zodiacs are periodically represented throughout their many art forms. [[Dushara]] was a principal male deity of the Nabataeans. He has been compared to Zeus in Greek culture as well as [[Dionysus]]. Examples of Dushara have been found in several places in Petra as well as [[Khirbet Et-Tannur]].<ref name="Zeyadine"/> Initially and traditionally, Dushara was represented in an aniconic form such as a square block, as is represented by the baetyls of Petra,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://nabataea.net/gods.html |title=Nabataean Religion: Pantheon |publisher=Nabataea.net |date= |accessdate=2013-02-03}}</ref> but there is a large amount of detailed sculpture found of Dushura. One specific piece shows a Hellenistic face, showing action and fleshy, vivacious characteristics.<ref name="civca">{{cite web|url=http://www.civilization.ca/cmc/exhibitions/cmc/petra/petra5e.shtml |title=PETRA: Lost City of Stone |language=fr |publisher=Civilization.ca |date= |accessdate=2013-02-03}}</ref> Other commonly represented Gods would include: [[Al-Uzza]], [[Al-Kutbay]], [[Nike (mythology)]], and the [[Zodiacs]].<ref name="civca"/>
===Betyls=== [[File:Basel 2012-08 Mattes 1 (215).JPG|thumb|alt=Betyl|Betyl]] Betyls ([[Baetylus]]) are another tool used for the representation of Gods and Goddesses beyond traditional sculpture. They appear in abundance in Nabataean art. They are often carved within shrines in both public and private places. Some have pedestals or are set within niches. Betyls were used to embody their gods, most often, although not exclusively, Dushara. They can be all sizes, in groups, or stand alone. They appear as relief sculpture and in the round. The carvings are rectangular and non-figural, though in some cases they have stylized eyes and a nose, similar to Aramic and South Arabian face stelae.<ref>Robert Wenning (2001). ''The Betyls of Petra.'' Bulletin of the American Schools of Oriental Research , No. 324, Nabataean Petra. pp. 79-95</ref>
==Painting==
Few instances of Nabataean painting have survived. Most are fragments of purely decorative interior painting. There has been enough to demonstrate, however, that they follow the contemporary [[Hellenistic art#Paintings and mosaics|Hellenistic style]], in which few paintings remain.<ref name="Guardian art article">{{cite news|last=Alberge|first=Dalya|title=Discovery of ancient cave paintings in Petra stuns art scholars|url=https://www.theguardian.com/science/2010/aug/22/hellenistic-wall-paintings-petra|newspaper=[[The Observer]]|date=21 August 2010|accessdate=14 April 2015}}</ref> [[File:Nabataean Painting Biclinium 849 Siq al-Barid Jordan1508.jpg|thumb|left|Ceiling frescoes in the Painted House at Little Petra|alt=A painted fresco with many dark spotted areas. In a clearer area closer to the bottom are vines, flowers, and a running squirrel]] In 2010, it was revealed that a biclinium, now known colloquially as the Painted House, at [[Little Petra]] in [[Jordan]] had extensive ceiling [[fresco]]es, which had long been concealed under soot from [[Bedouin]] campfires, and other inscriptions in the ensuing centuries. A three-year [[art restoration|restoration]] project had made them visible again. They depict, in extensive detail and with a variety of media, including [[glaze (painting technique)|glazes]] and [[gold leaf]], imagery such as grapevines and ''[[putto|putti]]'' associated with the Greek god [[Dionysus]], suggesting the space may have been used for wine consumption, perhaps with visiting merchants. In addition to being the only known example of Nabataean interior [[figurative art|figurative]] painting ''[[in situ]]'', they are one of the very few examples of Hellenistic painting extant, and have been considered superior to later Roman imitations of the style at [[Herculaneum]].<ref name="Guardian art article" />
== References == {{Commons category|Nabataeans}} {{reflist}}

{{Infobox award | name = National Prize for Plastic Arts | subheader = To the person who has distinguished himself by his achievements in the respective area of the arts | image = | image_size = | alt = | caption = | description = | sponsor = | location = | country = [[Chile]] | presenter = | year = 1992 | year2 = | website = | holder = }} The '''National Prize for Plastic Arts''' ({{lang-es|'''Premio Nacional de Artes Plásticas'''}}) was created in [[Chile]] in 1992 under Law 19169 as one of the replacements of the [[National Prize of Art of Chile|National Prize of Art]].<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.leychile.cl/Navegar?idNorma=30536&idVersion=1992-09-26 |title=Ley 19169: Establece normas sobre otorgamiento de Premios Nacionales |trans-title=Law 19169: Establishes Rules on Granting National Prizes |publisher=[[Ministry of Education (Chile)|Ministry of Education]] |language=Spanish |date=26 September 1992 |access-date=8 December 2017 |via=Library of the National Congress of Chile}}</ref> It is granted "to the person who has distinguished himself by his achievements in the respective area of the arts" (Article 8 of the aforementioned law). It is part of the [[National Prize of Chile]].
The prize, which is awarded every two years, consists of a diploma, the sum of 6,576,457 [[Chilean peso|pesos]] ({{US$|{{To USD|6576457|CHL|round=yes}}}}) which is adjusted every year, according to the previous year's [[consumer price index]], and a pension of 20 {{ill|Monthly tax unit|es|Unidad tributaria mensual|lt=monthly tax units}} (approximately US$1,600).
==Winners== * 1993, Sergio Montecinos Montalva * 1995, [[Lily Garafulic]]<ref>{{Cite news |url=http://www.latercera.com/noticia/muere-la-escultora-y-premio-nacional-de-arte-lily-garafulic/ |title=Muere la escultora y Premio Nacional de Arte Lily Garafulic |trans-title=The Sculptor and National Prize for Art Winner Lily Garafulic Dies |work=[[La Tercera]] |language=Spanish |date=15 May 2012 |access-date=12 December 2017}}</ref> * 1997, {{ill|Sergio Castillo Mandiola|es}} * 1999, [[José Balmes]] * 2001, {{ill|Rodolfo Opazo Bernales|es}} * 2003, {{ill|Gonzalo Díaz Cuevas|es}} * 2005, {{ill|Eugenio Dittborn|es}} * 2007, {{ill|Guillermo Núñez|es}} * 2009, {{ill|Federico Assler|es}} * 2011, [[Gracia Barrios]] * 2013, [[Alfredo Jaar]]<ref>{{Cite news |url=http://www.latercera.com/noticia/alfredo-jaar-premio-nacional-de-artes-en-chile-constate-la-tirania-de-las-capitales/ |title=Alfredo Jaar, Premio Nacional de Artes: 'En Chile constaté la tiranía de las capitales' |trans-title=Alfredo Jaar, National Prize for Arts: 'In Chile, I Verified the Tyranny of the Capitals' |work=[[La Tercera]] |language=Spanish |date=17 July 2016 |access-date=12 December 2017}}</ref> * 2015, [[Roser Bru]]<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://radio.uchile.cl/2015/08/24/roser-bru-gana-premio-nacional-de-artes-plasticas-2015/ |title=Roser Bru es elegida Premio Nacional de Artes Plásticas 2015 |trans-title=Roser Bru is Given 2015 National Prize for Plastic Arts |last=Alarcón |first=Rodrigo |publisher=[[University of Chile]] |language=Spanish |date=24 August 2015 '''Objectif Exhibitions''' (vzw) is a not-for-profit contemporary [[art center]] in [[Antwerp]], [[Belgium]].
==Mission== Objectif Exhibitions receives structural support from the Flemish Community, with which it supports international contemporary artists by producing exhibitions, events, and publications of and related to their work, and by providing production budgets and stipends directly to those artists. The [[art center]] reaches its local and international publics in person, through printed matter, and on the Internet. The current programme consists of simultaneous and overlapping solo exhibitions, which are presented at differing physical and temporal scales, and with correspondingly different mediation, as well as events, off-site projects, and publications.<ref name="rupert">{{cite web|url=http://www.rupert.lt/en/upcoming/chris-fitzpatrick-2012/|title=Rupert » Blog Archive » Chris Fitzpatrick: “2012″|publisher=rupert.lt|accessdate=2015-08-13}}</ref> The director is given autonomy over the programme by the board of directors, and a new director is hired every four years.<ref name="thewordmagazine">{{cite web|url=http://thewordmagazine.com/culture/belgiums-20-best-spaces-for-emerging-art/|title=20 of the best spaces for emerging art in Belgium today - The Word Magazine|publisher=thewordmagazine.com|accessdate=2015-08-13}}</ref>
==History== Objectif Exhibitions (originally typeset as "objectif_exhibitions")<ref name="objectif-exhibitions">{{cite web|url=http://www.objectif-exhibitions.org/1999-2007|title=objectif_exhibitions|publisher=objectif-exhibitions.org|accessdate=2015-08-13}}</ref> was founded in 1999 by [[Philippe Pirotte]], Win Van den Abbeele, and Patrick Van Rossem. [[Pirotte]] served as its first director from 1999 to 2004. When [[Pirotte]] became director of [[Kunsthalle Bern]], Van den Abbeele became the second director of Objectif Exhibitions. In 2007, Mai Abu ElDahab became the new director, and shifted the programmatic focus to one-person exhibitions, as well as publications and events. Chris Fitzpatrick is the current director, and was hired in 2012.<ref name="bamart">{{cite web|url=http://bamart.be/en/news/detail/7220/0/0/34/|title=Chris Fitzpatrick appointed new artistic director of Objectif-Exhibitions | Flanders Arts Institute|publisher=bamart.be|accessdate=2015-08-13}}</ref>
Objectif Exhibitions is currently located at Kleine Markt 7-9, and was moved to its current space in 2007 by ElDahab. [[Willem Elsschot]] once lived in the residence above, and the ground floor and basement facilities inspired Elsschot's classic novel "Kaas (Cheese)." Objectif Exhibitions was formerly located at Coquilhatstraat 14.
==Collaborations and Partnerships== AIR Antwerpen, Antwerp; Art Brussels, Brussels; [[Casco, Utrecht]]; Fundaion CELARG, Carracas; Circuit; [[Contemporary Art Centre (Vilnius)|Contemporary Art Centre]] (CAC), Vilnius; HALMOS, New York; Kadist Art Foundation, Paris; Kunsthalle Bern, Switzerland; Kunsthalle Sankt Gallen, Switzerland; Matrix Art Project; Middelheim Museum, Antwerp; M HKA, Antwerp; Piet Zwart Institute, Rotterdam; Platform; Sandberg Institute, Amsterdam; The Showroom, London; Townhouse, Cairo; Villa Croce, Genoa; and [[Yale Union]], Portland; among others.
==Exhibitions== Exhibitions have included a four-year exhibition by Nina Beier,<ref name="kunsthart">{{cite web|url=http://kunsthart.org/nl/21/68/chris-fitzpatrick-nieuw-artistiek-directeur-objectif-exhibitions.aspx|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140228041954/http://kunsthart.org/nl/21/68/chris-fitzpatrick-nieuw-artistiek-directeur-objectif-exhibitions.aspx |archive-date=2014-02-28 |dead-url=yes|title=kunsthart.org :: Chris Fitzpatrick, nieuw artistiek directeur Objectif Exhibitions :: HART Special :: Tijdschrift over hedendaagse kunst in België en omgeving|accessdate=2015-08-13}}</ref> a retrospective of [[Raphael Montañez Ortiz]]'s "Computer-Laser-Scratch" videos, and the first and only screening of lost [[Bruce Conner]] film, which David Kasprzak screened after collecting strips of film from a [[San Francisco]] bookstore for one year, interventions by Freek Wambacq in 14 different locations throughout Antwerp,<ref page.title: Otis College of Art and Design

revision.text:
{{Infobox University | name = Otis College of Art and Design | image = Otis College of Art and Design (logo).png | motto = | established = 1918 | type = [[Private school|Private]] [[art school]] & [[design school]] | president = Bruce W. Ferguson | city = [[Westchester, Los Angeles|Westchester]], [[Los Angeles]] | state = [[California]] | country = United States | campus = [[Urban area|Urban]] | undergrad = 1,093 | postgrad = 60 {{small|(MFA)}} | postgrad_label = | staff = | nickname = Owls | mascot = Otis Owl | free_label = | free = | website= {{url|www.otis.edu}} |}} '''Otis College of Art and Design''' is a private art school and design school in the [[Westchester, Los Angeles|Westchester]] neighborhood of [[Los Angeles]], California. Established in 1918, it was the city's first independent professional school of art.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://aicad.org/schools/otis-college-of-art-and-design/|work=Association of Independent Colleges of Art and Design|title=Otis College of Art and Design|archive-url=http://archive.is/xKIxZ|archive-date=November 8, 2018}}</ref> The main campus is located in the former [[IBM|IBM Aerospace]] Headquarters at 9045 [[Lincoln Boulevard (Southern California)|Lincoln Boulevard]] in Westchester, Los Angeles.
The school's programs, accredited by [[Western Association of Schools and Colleges|WASC]] and [[National Association of Schools of Art and Design]], include four-year BFA degrees in [[illustration]], [[fine art]]s, [[graphic design]], [[architecture]], [[landscape design]], [[interior design]], [[fashion design]], [[digital media]], [[toy|toy design]], and [[product design]]. It also offers MFA degrees in [[fine arts]], [[graphic design]], public practice, and [[writing]].
Undergraduate students choose a major in their second year, after completing a battery of traditional drawing, painting, composition, and construction classes in their first or "Foundation" year. In addition to studio work, standard [[liberal arts]] courses are required, although traditional history courses are replaced by [[art history]].
== History == [[File:Otiscollege.jpg|thumb|right|upright=1|The Ahmanson building at Otis College of Art and Design]] Otis, long considered one of the major art institutions in California, began in 1918, when ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'' founder [[Harrison Gray Otis (publisher)|Harrison Gray Otis]] bequeathed his [[Westlake, Los Angeles]], property to start the first public, independent professional school of art in Southern California. The current Otis College main campus (since Spring 1997) is located in the Westchester area of Los Angeles, close to the [[Los Angeles International Airport]]. The main building (built in 1963) was designed by architect [[Eliot Noyes]] for IBM and is famous for its computer "[[punched card]]" style windows.<ref>{{cite web |title=The IBM Punched Card |url=http://www-03.ibm.com/ibm/history/ibm100/us/en/icons/punchcard/impacts/}}</ref>
The building was extensively remodeled in 1997 by the college when it moved from its original location across the street from [[MacArthur Park]] near downtown Los Angeles.<ref>{{cite web |title=Otis College of Art and Design Timeline/History |url=http://www.otis.edu/history-timeline|accessdate=6 November 2014}}</ref> The Galef Center, made for the Fine Arts department, was designed by Fredrick Fisher and built in 2001.
A [[ceramic art|ceramics]] school was begun by [[Peter Voulkos]] at Otis in the 1950s and was part of art movements like the Craft-to-Art movement, also known as the [[American Clay Revolution]],<ref>{{cite web |title=PETER VOULKOS |work=ArtScene |accessdate=2012-08-05 |url=http://artscenecal.com/ArticlesFile/Archive/Articles1996/Articles0296/Voulkos.html}}</ref> which influenced the [[Ferus Gallery]] scene of the 1960s. Many prominent artists associated with Southern California’s Light and Space movement were involved with the school, as well as leaders of the conceptual art world of the 1970s. Moreover, Otis nurtured significant Latino artists, and the mural group [[Los Four]] also originated at Otis in the 1970s.
The school was originally named Otis Art Institute. From 1978 until 1991, it was affiliated with New York's [[Parsons School of Design]] and known as Otis-Parsons (full name: Otis Art Institute of Parsons School of Design, A Division of the New School for Social Research).<ref>{{cite web|work=[[The New York Times]]|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1979/05/17/archives/parsons-and-otis-art-school-merger.html|title=Parsons and Otis: Art School Merger|date=May 17, 1979|p=5}}</ref> This affiliation allowed students to spend a semester or more at the Parsons schools in New York and Paris. In 1991, it became independent and known as Otis College of Art and Design.
Today it is one of the most culturally diverse private schools of art and design in the country.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lalouver.com/resource/otis/otis.pdf|title=OTIS: NINE DECADES OF LOS ANGELES ART EXHIBITION HIGHLIGHT LASTING IMPACT OF LA ARTISTS & MOVEMENTS|location=Los Angeles, CA|date= October 12, 2005}}</ref>
==Rankings and reputation==
''[[The Economist]]'' ranked Otis College of Art and Design 6th among national universities in its [[The Economist Magazine's List of America's Best Colleges|2015 ranking of the U.S. best colleges]] for 'Value of Education'<ref>{{cite web|author=The Economist |url=https://www.economist.com/news/united-states/21677231-new-federal-data-reveal-which-colleges-do-most-their-graduates-pay-packets-they-are|title=The Economist: List of America's Best Colleges |publisher=The Economist |date=2015 |accessdate=October 31, 2015}}</ref> based on sophisticated evaluation method and by alumni earnings above expectation.<ref>{{cite web|author=The Economist |url=https://www.economist.com/blogs/graphicdetail/2015/10/value-university|title=The Economist: Value of University: Rankings Details |publisher=The Economist |date=2015 |accessdate=October 28, 2015}}</ref> ''[[Money Magazine]]'' ranked Otis fourth for "Best Value Added College."<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.otis.edu/news/otis-college-4-money-magazines-best-value-added-colleges|title=Otis College #4 in Money Magazine's Best Value-Added Colleges|website=Otis College of Art and Design|language=en|access-date=2018-01-26}}</ref>
== BFA programs == Otis is well known for its BFA degrees offered in [[fashion design]]. Under the direction of [[Rosemary Brantley]], this program is considered one of the top fashion design programs of its kind in the U.S.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thefutureschannel.com/conversations_archive/wickser_conversation.php|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111121020708/http://thefutureschannel.com/conversations_archive/wickser_conversation.php|archivedate=12 November 2011|title=Jackie Wickser|publisher=The Future Channel}}</ref> Otis Fashion Design is housed at the California Market Center in downtown Los Angeles.
Students benefit from working closely with design mentors and are trained in all aspects of the design process while emulating a fashion design studio, and following the industry’s seasonal schedule. Visiting critics have included designers such as [[Bob Mackie]], [[Francisco Costa (designer)|Francisco Costa]] for [[Calvin Klein]], [[Vera Wang]], [[Diane von Fürstenberg]], [[Isabel Toledo]], [[Isaac Mizrahi]], and [[Todd Oldham]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.otis.edu/about/press/fashion_mentors_07.html|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120307085847/http://www.otis.edu/about/press/fashion_mentors_07.html|archivedate=7 March 2012|title=Fashion Design Mentors for 2007}}</ref> Major designers such as [[Eduardo Lucero]] and [[Rick Owens]] are alumni of the program.
== Selected faculty (current and past) == Notable faculty members include [[Judie Bamber]], [[Guy Bennett]], [[Andrea Bowers]], [[Rosemary Brantley]], [[Sarah Shun-lien Bynum]], [[Carole Caroompas]], [[Meg Cranston]], [[Marlena Donohue]], [[Roy Dowell]], [[Peter Gadol]], [[Michael Gira]], [[Scott Grieger]], [[Michele Jaquis]], [[Annetta Kapon]], [[Susan E. King]], [[Soo Kim]], [[Suzanne Lacy]], [[Laida Lertxundi]], [[Marisa Matarazzo]], [[Christian Mounger]], [[Harry Mott]], [[Kali Nikitas]], [[Renee Petropoulos]], [[Joan Takayama-Ogawa]], [[Paul Vangelisti]], [[Charles Wilbert White]] and [[Michael Ragsdale Wright]], [[Linda Pollari]], [[Kate Johnson (digital media)|Kate Johnson]] and Willie Nelson.
== Artists-in-Residence == * Past (1940s): [[Norman Rockwell]] * 2005: [[Shahzia Sikander]] * 2006: [[Masami Teraoka]] * 2007: [[Nancy Chunn]] * 2008: [[Mark Dean Veca]]
== Distinguished alumni == * 1920s: [[Bob Clampett]], [[Ralston Crawford]], [[Harwell Hamilton Harris]], [[Edith Head]], [[Arthur Hill Gilbert]], [[John Hench]], [[Paul Landacre]], [[Ben H. Lewis]],<ref>Paul, Arthur G. ''Riverside Community Book'', A. H. Causton, Riverside, CA, 1954. Page 269.</ref> [[Edward L. Thrasher]], [[Milford Zornes]], [[Wilfred Jackson]], [[Thomas McKimson]], [[George Stanley (sculptor)]], [[Alice Taylor Gafford]] * 1930s: [[Gladys Aller]] [[Philip Guston]], [[Dorothy Jeakins]], [[Tyrus Wong]], [[Hideo Date]] * 1940s: [[John Altoon]], [[Joseph Mugnaini]], [[George Chann]] * 1950s: [[John Baldessari]], [[Billy Al Bengston]], [[Robert Irwin (artist)|Robert Irwin]], [[John Mason (artist)|John Mason]], [[Paul Soldner]], [[Tom Van Sant]], [[Stan Bitters]], [[Kenneth Price]], [[Dean Tavoularis]], [[Virginia Jaramillo (artist)|Virginia Jaramillo]] * 1960s: [[Bas Jan Ader]], [[Barry Le Va]], [[Masami Teraoka]], [[John Lees (artist)|John Lees]], Richard Pettibone, [[Norman Zammitt]] * 1970s: [[Carlos Almaraz]], [[Alonzo Davis]], [[Dorothy Faison]], [[Kim Gordon]], [[David Hammons]], [[Judithe Hernández]], [[Bryan Hunt]], [[Kerry James Marshall]], [[May Sun]], [[Kent Twitchell]], [[Bruce Yonemoto]], [[Coleen Sterritt]], Roberto Gil de Montes, [[Judithe Hernandez]] * 1980s: [[Diane Gamboa]], [[Lawrence Gipe]], [[Rebecca Jo Morales]], [[Jim Rygiel]], [[Alison Saar]], [[Michael S. Smith (interior designer)|Michael S. Smith]], [[Patssi Valdez]], [[Jeffrey Vallance]], [[Darren Waterston]], [[Ruben Ochoa]], [[Sandow Birk]], [[Tim Biskup]], [[Rick Owens]], [[Sarah Perry]], [[Steve Roden]], [[Mark Dean Veca]], [[Dawn Baillie]] * 1990s: [[Abhay Deol]], [[Gajin Fujita]], [[Camille Rose Garcia]], [[Eduardo Lucero]], [[Khoi Vinh]], [[Hideko Takahashi]], [[Emma Ferreira]], [[Garth Trinidad]] [[Claire Pettibone]]. * 2000s: [[David Tai Bornoff]], [[Faris McReynolds]], [[Hana Mae Lee]], [[Mayuka Thaïs]] * 2010s: [[Kour Pour]]
== Ben Maltz Gallery == The [[Ben Maltz Gallery]] at Otis College is a professional art space that presents group and solo exhibitions in a variety of media. The Gallery's main focus is showcasing [[contemporary art]] that pushes the boundaries of form and subject matter in the context of national and international programming. Serving the local art community, the public, and Otis students and faculty, the Maltz Gallery presents emerging and established local as well as international artists.
== In culture == The film ''[[Art School Confidential (film)|Art School Confidential]]'' (2006) was partially filmed at Otis. Otis Foundation Professor Gary Geraths worked as a consultant on the film.<ref>{{cite web|work=Otis.edu|publisher=Otis College of Art and Design|url=https://www.otis.edu/faculty/gary-geraths|title=Gary Geraths|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140817101037/https://www.otis.edu/faculty/gary-geraths|archive-date=August 17, 2014}}</ref>

page.title: Pablo Neruda Order of Artistic and Cultural Merit

revision.text:
{{Infobox award | name = Pablo Neruda Order of Artistic and Cultural Merit | subheader = | image = Joan Turner, viuda de Víctor Jara (2).jpg | image_size = | alt = | caption = [[Joan Jara|Joan Turner]] at the 2016 award ceremony | description = Contributions made in the field of art and culture | sponsor = [[National Council of Culture and the Arts (Chile)|National Council of Culture and the Arts]] | location = | country = [[Chile]] | presenter = | year = 2004 | year2 = | website = | holder = }} The '''Pablo Neruda Order of Artistic and Cultural Merit''' ({{lang-es|'''Orden al Mérito Artístico y Cultural Pablo Neruda'''}}) was created in 2004 by the [[National Council of Culture and the Arts (Chile)|National Council of Culture and the Arts]] of the government of [[Chile]], as part of the commemoration of the 100th anniversary of the birth of Chilean poet [[Pablo Neruda]] (12 July 1904).<ref name=Postino>{{Cite web |url=http://www.cultura.gob.cl/ministro/en-estreno-mundial-de-%e2%80%98il-postino%e2%80%99-ministro-de-cultura-entrego-orden-al-merito-pablo-neruda/ |title=En estreno mundial de 'Il Postino': Ministro de Cultura entregó Orden al Mérito Pablo Neruda |trans-title=World Premiere of 'Il Postino': Minister of Culture Delivered Pablo Neruda Order of Merit |publisher=[[National Council of Culture and the Arts (Chile)|National Council of Culture and the Arts]] |language=Spanish |date=24 September 2010 |access-date=11 January 2018}}</ref>
It is granted by the Minister of Culture to those national and international figures who have stood out for contributions made in the field of art and culture.
The Pablo Neruda Order of Merit was delivered for the first time on 5 July 2004 to the mayor of Barcelona, [[Joan Clos]], and about 15 Ibero-American artists – among them, [[Miguel Bosé]], [[Joan Manuel Serrat]], [[Víctor Manuel]], [[Ana Belén]], [[Jorge Drexler]], [[Julieta Venegas]], and {{ill|Antonio Ríos (musician)|es|Antonio Ríos|lt=Antonio Ríos}} – who participated in the {{ill|Neruda en el corazón|es}} musical tribute that took place at the [[Palau Sant Jordi]], Barcelona.<ref name=Brouwer>{{Cite news |url=http://www.elmostrador.cl/cultura/2007/12/01/otorgan-a-musico-cubano-leo-brouwer-la-orden-al-merito-pablo-neruda/?php%20bloginfo(%27url%27);%20?%3E/cultura |title=Otorgan a músico cubano Leo Brouwer la Orden al Mérito Pablo Neruda |trans-title=Cuban Musician Leo Brouwer Awarded the Pablo Neruda Order of Merit |work=[[El Mostrador]] |language=Spanish |date=1 December 2007 |access-date=11 January 2018}}</ref>
Many national and international personalities have received this decoration since it was created.
==Recipients== ===2005=== * [[Carmen Beuchat]], choreographer (5 March 2005 – [[International Women's Day]]) * [[Isidora Aguirre]], dramatist and writer (5 March 2005 – International Women's Day) * [[María Elena Gertner]], screenwriter, dramatist, and actress (5 March 2005 – International Women's Day) * [[Roser Bru]], visual artist (5 March 2005 – International Women's Day)<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.cooperativa.cl/noticias/cultura/literatura/pablo-neruda/cuatro-destacadas-mujeres-recibieron-la-medalla-pablo-neruda/2005-03-05/173126.html |title=Cuatro destacadas mujeres recibieron la Medalla Pablo Neruda |trans-title=Four Distinguished Women Receive the Pablo Neruda Medal |publisher=[[Radio Cooperativa]] |language=Spanish |access-date=18 January 2018}}</ref> * {{ill|Juan Luis Ysern de Arce|es}}, Bishop of [[Roman Catholic Diocese of San Carlos de Ancud|Ancud]] (1 April 2005 – launch of Project SISMO) * [[Roberto Parra Sandoval|Roberto Parra]], popular singer-songwriter; awarded to his widow Catalina Rojas (21 April 2005) * Hernán Baldrich, dancer and choreographer (28 April 2005 – Day of the Dance) * [[Tito Beltrán]], Chilean tenor (25 July 2005) * {{ill|Patricio Bunster|es}}, choreographer (28 August 2005 – 2nd National Culture Convention) * Tomás Chotzen, President of ANDES Foundation (28 August 2005 – 2nd National Culture Convention) * {{ill|Mariano Silva (writer)|es|Mariano Silva|lt=Mariano Silva}}, film critic (28 August 2005 – 2nd National Culture Convention) * [[Patricio Guzmán]], filmmaker (31 August 2005 – Chilean premiere of documentary ''[[Salvador Allende (film)|Salvador Allende]]'') * [[Carmen Brito]], filmmaker and restorer (17 October 2005 – National Film Inauguration Day) * {{ill|Pedro Chaskel|es}}, film editor and director (17 October 2005 – National Film Inauguration Day) * {{ill|Sergio Bravo (screenwriter)|es|Sergio Bravo|lt=Sergio Bravo}}, filmmaker and documentalist (17 October 2005 – National Film Inauguration Day) * [[Delia Domínguez]], writer (14 December 2005 – Closing Quixote Reading Program) * Marta Cruz-Coke, cultural manager (14 December 2005 – Closing Quixote Reading Program) * [[Margot Loyola]], folklorist (29 December 2005 – Valparaíso Cultural Carnival)
===2006=== * [[Bono]] (Paul David Hewson), [[U2]] vocalist (26 February 2006 – [[La Moneda Palace]]) * [[Alejandro Jodorowsky]], writer and filmmaker (27 April 2006 – La Moneda Palace) * [[Rubén Blades]], musician and Minister of Tourism of Panama (27 December 2006 – La Moneda Palace)
===2007=== * [[Pina Bausch]], German choreographer (11 January 2007 – La Moneda Palace) * [[Luis Alarcón]], Chilean actor (26 September 2007 – La Moneda Palace) * [[Julio Bocca]], Argentine dancer (24 November 2007 – La Moneda Palace)<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.cooperativa.cl/noticias/cultura/arte/danza/un-emocionado-julio-bocca-fue-galardonado-en-la-moneda/2007-11-24/161750.html |title=Un emocionado Julio Bocca fue galardonado en La Moneda |trans-title=An Excited Julio Bocca Was Winner at La Moneda |publisher=[[Radio Cooperativa]] |language=Spanish |access-date=11 January 2018}}</ref> * [[Leo Brouwer]], Cuban composer and musician (1 December 2007 – La Moneda Palace)<ref name=Brouwer/>
===2008=== * [[Ennio Morricone]], Italian film score composer (19 March 2008 – La Moneda Palace)
===2009=== * Isaac Frenkel, benefactor of music in Chile, ex-President of the Beethoven Foundation (27 August 2009 – La Moneda Palace)<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://diarioiquique.wordpress.com/2009/08/28/jefa-de-estado-entrego-orden-al-merito-artistico-y-cultural-pablo-neruda-a-isaac-frenkel/ |title=Jefa de Estado entregó orden al mérito artístico y cultural Pablo Neruda a Isaac Frenkel |trans-title=Head of State Gives Pablo Neruda Order of Artistic and Cultural Merit to Isaac Frenkel |last=Pardo Aedo |first=Oscar Alejandro |work=Diario de Cuatro a Seis |language=Spanish |date=28 August 2009 |access-date=11 January 2018}}</ref>
===2010=== * [[Laura Esquivel]], Mexican writer (21 January 2010 – La Moneda Palace)<ref>{{Cite news |url=http://latercera.com/contenido/1453_219746_9.shtml |title=Escritora mexicana Laura Esquivel recibe Orden al mérito Pablo Neruda |trans-title=Mexican Writer Laura Esquivel Receives Pablo Neruda Order of Merit |work=[[La Tercera]] |agency=UPI |language=Spanish |date=21 January 2010 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120114090144/http://latercera.com/contenido/1453_219746_9.shtml |archive-date=14 January 2012 |dead-url=yes |access-date=11 January 2018}}</ref> * [[Cristina Gallardo-Domâs]], lyrical singer (23 September 2010 – Los Angeles Opera Theater, California) * [[Plácido Domingo]], Spanish singer and opera director (23 September 2010 – Los Angeles Opera Theater, California) * [[Daniel Catán]], Mexican composer and musician (23 September 2010 – Los Angeles Opera Theater, California) * [[Antonio Skármeta]], writer (23 September 2010 – Los Angeles Opera Theater, California)<ref name=Postino/>
===2012=== * {{ill|Miguel Castillo Didier|es}}, scholar of Greek culture (27 March 2014 – Sala América, [[Biblioteca Nacional de Chile|Biblioteca Nacional]])<ref>{{Cite news |url=http://www.latercera.com/noticia/cultura/2012/03/1453-440431-9-ministro-cruzcoke-entrega-orden-al-merito-artistico-y-cultural-pablo-neruda-a.shtml |title=Ministro Cruz-Coke entrega Orden al Mérito Artístico y Cultural Pablo Neruda a Miguel Castillo Didier |trans-title=Minister Cruz-Coke Delivers Pablo Neruda Order of Artistic and Cultural Merit to Miguel Castillo Didier |work=[[La Tercera]] |language=Spanish |date=28 March 2012 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160305024027/http://www.latercera.com/noticia/cultura/2012/03/1453-440431-9-ministro-cruzcoke-entrega-orden-al-merito-artistico-y-cultural-pablo-neruda-a.shtml |archive-date=5 March 2016 |access-date=11 January 2018}}</ref> * [[Lucho Gatica]], singer (25 November 2012 – Chile Pavilion at the Guadalajara Book Fair, Mexico)<ref>{{Cite news |url=http://www.emol.com/noticias/magazine/2012/11/25/571427/cantante-lucho-gatica-recibe-la-orden-al-merito-pablo-neruda.html |title=Cantante Lucho Gatica es condecorado con la Orden al Mérito Pablo Neruda |trans-title=Singer Lucho Gatica is Decorated with the Pablo Neruda Order of Merit |work=[[El Mercurio]] |location=Guadalajara |language=Spanish |date=25 November 2012 |access-date=11 January 2018}}</ref>
===2013=== * [[Los Jaivas]], experimental rock band (30 September 2013 - Muelle Prat, Valparaíso)<ref>{{Cite news |url=http://www.emol.com/noticias/magazine/2013/09/30/622214/los-jaivas-reciben-orden-pablo-neruda.html |title=Los Jaivas reciben en Valparaíso la Orden al Mérito Pablo Neruda |trans-title=Los Jaivas Receive the Pablo Neruda Order of Merit in Valparaíso |work=[[El Mercurio]] |location=Santiago |language=Spanish |date=30 September 2013 |access-date=11 January 2018}}</ref>
===2014=== * [[Raquel Barros]], folklorist, researcher, and academic (30 January 2014 - Severín Library, Valparaíso) * [[Matilde Pérez]], visual artist (30 January 2014 - Severín Library, Valparaíso) * [[Paz Errázuriz]], photographer (30 January 2014 - Severín Library, Valparaíso) * [[Alejandro Sieveking]], dramatist (30 January 2014 - Severín Library, Valparaíso) * Luis Cárdenas, circus trapeze artist (30 January 2014 - Severín Library, Valparaíso) * [[Themo Lobos]], writer; posthumous decoration (30 January 2014 - Severín Library, Valparaíso) * [[Cuarteto Latinoamericano]], musical group (30 January 2014 - Severín Library, Valparaíso) * Fernando García, learned music composer (30 January 2014 - Severín Library, Valparaíso) * [[Gabriel Valdés]], diplomat and politician; posthumous decoration (30 January 2014 - Severín Library, Valparaíso) * Los Blue Splendor, musical group (30 January 2014 - Severín Library, Valparaíso) * Arturo Navarro, manager of the Mapocho Station Cultural Center (30 January 2014 - Severín Library, Valparaíso) * Nicola Schiess, executive director of the Teatro del Lago, Frutillar (30 January 2014 - Severín Library, Valparaíso)<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.cultura.gob.cl/institucional/ministro-ampuero-entrega-orden-al-merito-pablo-neruda-a-12-personalidades-del-mundo-artistico-nacional/ |title=Consejo de la Cultura entrega Orden al Mérito Pablo Neruda a 12 personalidades del mundo artístico nacional |trans-title=Council of Cultura Delivers Pablo Neruda Order of Merit to 12 Personalities of the National Artistic World |publisher=[[National Council of Culture and the Arts (Chile)|National Council of Culture and the Arts]] |language=Spanish |date=30 January 2014 |access-date=11 January 2018}}</ref>
===2015=== * [[Quino]], Argentine writer and cartoonist of [[Mafalda]] (15 January 2015 - Gabriela Mistral Cultural Center)<ref name=presidencia>{{Cite web |url=https://prensa.presidencia.cl/discurso.aspx?id=31773 |title=Ceremonia de Condecoración 'Orden al Mérito Artístico y Cultural Pablo Neruda' |trans-title=Decoration Ceremony 'Pablo Neruda Order of Artistic and Cultural Merit' |publisher=Office of the [[President of Chile]] |language=Spanish |date=28 April 2016 |access-date=11 January 2018}}</ref>
===2016=== * {{ill|Valentín Trujillo (pianist)|es|Valentín Trujillo (pianista)|lt=Valentín Trujillo}}, Chilean musician * {{ill|Vicente Bianchi|es}}, Chilean musician * [[Bélgica Castro]], Chilean actress * {{ill|Claudio di Girolamo|es}}, Chilean painter, dramatist, and cultural advisor * Alicia del Carmen Cáceres, Chilean goldsmith * [[Joan Jara|Joan Turner]], Chilean-British dancer<ref name=presidencia/><ref name=González>{{Cite web |url=http://www.cooperativa.cl/noticias/entretencion/musica/jorge-gonzalez/jorge-gonzalez-recibira-la-orden-al-merito-pablo-neruda/2016-12-30/111928.html |title=Jorge González recibirá la Orden al Mérito Pablo Neruda |trans-title=Jorge González to Receive the Pablo Neruda Order of Merit |publisher=[[Radio Cooperativa]] |language=Spanish |access-date=11 January 2018}}</ref>
===2017=== * [[Jorge González (musician)|Jorge González]], Chilean musician, singer, and composer; leader of the band [[Los Prisioneros]] (7 January 2017 - Summit of Chilean Rock, [[Estadio Nacional Julio Martínez Prádanos|Estadio Nacional]])<ref name=González/> * Humberto Duvauchelle, Chilean actor and academic (11 July 2017 - [[University of Concepción]] Theater)<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.24horas.cl/tendencias/espectaculosycultura/otorgan-orden-al-merito-artistico-y-cultural-pablo-neruda-a-humberto-duvauchelle--2445225 |title=Otorgan 'Orden al Mérito Artístico y Cultural Pablo Neruda' a Humberto Duvauchelle |trans-title='Pablo Neruda Order of Artistic and Cultural Merit' Awarded to Humberto Duvauchelle |publisher=[[24 Horas]] |language=Spanish |date=11 July 2017 |access-date=11 January 2018}}</ref> * Juan Allende-Blin, composer (9 September 2017 - [[University of Chile]] Theater)<ref>{{Cite news |url=http://www.emol.com/noticias/Espectaculos/2017/09/09/874649/El-compositor-chileno-Juan-AllendeBlin-recibe-la-Orden-al-Merito-Pablo-Neruda.html |title=El compositor chileno Juan Allende-Blin recibe la Orden al Mérito Pablo Neruda |trans-title=The Chilean Composer Juan Allende-Blin Receives the Pablo Neruda Order of Merit |last=Troncoso M. |first=Constanza |work=[[El Mercurio]] |location=Santiago |language=Spanish |date=9 September 2017 |access-date=11 January 2018}}</ref>
==See also== * [[Pablo Neruda Award]], granted by the Neruda Foundation to poets under 40 * [[Pablo Neruda Ibero-American Poetry Award]], also given by the CNCA
